p: Fuentes ( 2006) further elaborates these descriptions of human/macaque behavior by recording the time of day and precise location in which they occurred as well as the humans’ and macaques’ relative positions in space. His research shows that while the broader contexts of interaction in these monkey parks may appear similar—the presence of European tourists, a domesticated macaque population—on closer inspection, striking differences emerge: In Bali, locals are more likely to be involved in the interactions; in Gibraltar, the most substantial interface is mediated by taxi and coach drivers who attempt to elicit responses from macaques for the sake of the tourists who have hired them.
